Detailed Description

MimeCoding

MIME Content-Transfer-Encoding as defined in RFC 1521, chapter 5

Author:
Christoph Bartelmus

Member Function Documentation

INT MimeCoding::DecodeBase64 (  CHAR *  buffer,
INT  buffer_length,
const CHAR *  data,
INT  data_length,
BOOLEAN  is_text
)  [static]
 

decode given BASE64 data

Parameters:
buffer,: output buffer provided by caller
buffer_length,: size of output buffer in bytes
data,: input data buffer
data_length,: size of data buffer in bytes
is_text,: set to TRUE if the data consists of text (note that the encoding will behave differently depending on whether the data is text or binary)
Returns:
number of bytes of the output used during decoding, -1 if the output buffer was too small to hold the data or an error occured during decoding

Returns:

INT MimeCoding::EncodeBase64 (  CHAR *  buffer,
INT  buffer_length,
const CHAR *  data,
INT  data_length,
BOOLEAN  is_text
)  [static]
 

transform given data to BASE64 Encoding

The size of the output after encoding will be about 33 percent bigger than the size of the input buffer.

Parameters:
buffer,: output buffer provided by caller
buffer_length,: size of output buffer in bytes
data,: input data buffer
data_length,: size of data buffer in bytes
is_text,: set to TRUE if the data consists of text (note that the encoding will behave differently depending on whether the data is text or binary)
Returns:
number of bytes of the output used during encoding, -1 if the output buffer was too small to hold the data

INT MimeCoding::EncodeQuotedPrintable (  CHAR *  buffer,
INT  buffer_length,
const CHAR *  data,
INT  data_length,
BOOLEAN  is_text
)  [static]
 

encode given data to Quoted-Printable Encoding

Note that if the input consists mostly of binary data, then you should consider BASE64 encoding as Quoted-Printable is only efficient for data that consists mainly of ASCII characters.

Parameters:
buffer,: output buffer provided by caller
buffer_length,: size of output buffer in bytes
data,: input data buffer
data_length,: size of data buffer in bytes
is_text,: set to TRUE if the data consists of text (note that the encoding will behave differently depending on whether the data is text or binary)
Returns:
number of bytes of the output used during encoding, -1 if the output buffer was too small to hold the data
